speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is praying that God will bless Romeo and Juliet's marriage so that their future is not filled with regret and sadness. He is expressing his hope that this joyful union will not later be the cause of their suffering.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar hopes God will bless the marriage so they won't later regret it with sadness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling Friar Laurence that any future sorrow is insignificant compared to the joy he gets from seeing Juliet. He urges the Friar to marry them immediately, saying that even if their love leads to his death, it will be worth it as long as he can call Juliet his wife.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares that no future sorrow can outweigh the joy he gets from even a brief moment with Juliet. He tells Friar Lawrence to marry them immediately, saying that even if death comes for them afterward, he'll be content just having her as his wife. 'Countervail' means 'equal or outweigh,' and 'love-devouring death' is a metaphor for death that consumes lovers.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar warns that intense passions burn out quickly and self-destruct, just as gunpowder explodes when ignited. He advises that extreme love can become sickening, so moderation ensures lasting affection. Rushing into love is as unwise as moving too slowly.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence warns that intense pleasures lead to destructive outcomes, burning out quickly like gunpowder ignited by fire. Even something delightful like honey becomes sickening if overindulged. He advises balanced love—both rushing and delaying love are equally problematic.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet greets Friar Laurence with a playful, respectful title, calling him her "ghostly confessor"—a term for a priest who hears confessions. This sets a warm, trusting tone for their conversation about her secret marriage to Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet greets Friar Lawrence as her spiritual advisor. 'Good even' means 'good evening' and 'ghostly confessor' refers to a priest who hears confessions and provides spiritual guidance.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is speaking to Juliet, assuring her that Romeo will express gratitude on behalf of both of them. This line emphasizes the Friar's role in uniting the couple and his hope that their marriage will bring peace.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence tells Juliet that Romeo will express gratitude on behalf of both of them. 'Ghostly confessor' means spiritual advisor (confessor). He calls Juliet 'daughter' as a term of spiritual affection, showing their priest-penitent relationship.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Friar Laurence that she will give Romeo as much love as he gives her; otherwise, Romeo's gratitude would be excessive. She is emphasizing the equal and reciprocal nature of their love, assuring the Friar that her commitment matches Romeo's.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet means she gives Romeo equal love and devotion, so if he thanks her for anything less than that, his gratitude would be excessive. 'As much to him' indicates reciprocal affection, while 'else is his thanks too much' suggests imbalance would make his appreciation unwarranted.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying that if Juliet is as joyful as he is, and if she is better at expressing it, she should speak aloud so her words can make the air around them sweet and reveal the happiness they both feel from being together. He uses "blazon" to mean proclaim or announce, and "unfold" to mean reveal or describe.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says if Juliet's happiness equals his and she's better at expressing it, she should speak aloud so her words can describe the joy they both feel from being together. 'Measure' means amount; 'heap'd' means piled up; 'blazon' means to proclaim or display; 'sweeten with thy breath' means speak; 'rich music's tongue' refers to her beautiful voice; 'unfold' means reveal; 'imagin'd happiness' means the joy they envision; 'receive in either' means each receives from the other.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet argues that genuine love is too profound to be captured by mere words or superficial boasts. She believes those who can quantify their love's value are actually poor in it, whereas her own love for Romeo has grown so immense she cannot calculate even half of its worth. This emphasizes her overwhelming, inexpressible devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says that true feeling is more substantial than elaborate descriptions—fancy words just boast about decoration rather than substance. She compares people who can tally their love's value to beggars (implying it's small), but her love for Romeo is so immense she can't calculate even half of its worth.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is telling Romeo and Juliet to come with him quickly to be married. He insists they won't be left alone together until after the wedding ceremony has officially joined them as one. This shows his urgency to formalize their union and prevent any premarital intimacy.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar urges them to come with him quickly to the wedding ceremony. 'By your leaves' means 'with your permission'—a polite phrase. He says they won't be left alone until marriage ('holy church incorporate two in one') unites them. Paraphrase: Let's go quickly to the chapel; you won't be alone until you're married.
